p: Not only the composition but also the temperature has a strong influence on the Eu 3+ emission. At −20 °C (Fig. 2b) the spectra of the ferroelectric ceramics (BZ0, BZ5 and BZ15) are dominated by the 5D 0 → 7F 4 bands whose integrated intensity is three and a half times larger compared to the 5D 0 → 7F 1 transition that is the most intense at room temperature. All other bands, and in particular the 5D 0 → 7F 2 one, have a much lower intensity. The 5D 0 → 7F 4 transition is the strongest even in sample BZ30 in comparison to RT. The spectra of BZ50, BZ70 and BZ100 are instead very similar to those observed at room temperature. At −100 °C (Fig. 2c), the 5D 0 → 7F 4 transition is the most intense for all ceramics except BZ100, for which it has the same order of magnitude as 5D 0 → 7F 1 and 5D 0 → 7F 2. No significant changes in the shape of PL spectra of ferroelectric ceramics are observed between −20 and −100 °C. It is worth noting that band broadening in the PL spectra of relaxors is unaffected by temperature variations.
